prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cluster GEEC 138 - 10 blue galaxies at z=0.44

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use continuum measurements of the dust emission to measure the total gas content (Scoville 2013). We aim for a 5 sigma continuum detection of galaxies containing 5E9 Msun of gas (HI+H2). We assume T(dust)=20 K, as seen in many nearby galaxy surveys (e.g. Dale et al. 2012). We adopt the dust emissivity parameters from recent Planck observations of regions containg molecular gas (Planck Collaboration 2011): kappa(250 microns)=14 cm^2/g, beta=1.8, gas-to-dust mass ratio = 100. We use the equation for dust mass from Wilson et al. (2013) rewritten into a more convenient form for these redshifted clusters:
M(gas) = 3.20E-8 S_nu D_L^2 lambda_{rest}^4.8 [exp(h nu_{rest}/kT) -1]
with M(gas) in Msun, S_nu in Jy, D_L in Mpc and lambda_{rest} in microns. (See page 4 of proposal text for a latex'd display of the formula.)
For this cluster at redshift 0.44 (luminosity distance 2420 Mpc), the mean observed frequency of 345 GHz translates into a rest frequency of 497 GHz and a rest wavelength of 604 microns. The expected signal is 0.52 mJy for a galaxy with 5E9 Msun of gas. Galaxies with more gas will be detected with higher S/N.
The correlator configuration is for a standard continuum measurement in Band 7.

With an angular diameter distance of 1167 Mpc, the 1" ALMA beam corresponds to a diameter of 5.6 kpc. This resolution is well matched to observed diameter of the bright central regions in the most gas-rich Virgo Cluster galaxies, such as NGC 4254 or NGC 4321 (Wilson et al. 2012). Due to the right ascension of this particular cluster and the ALMA schedule for the most compact configuration, 0.5" resolution would also be acceptable for this cluster.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cluster GEEC 38 - 11 blue galaxies at z=0.51

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
See ScienceGoal "Cluster GEEC 138" for a description of the equation and input parameters.
For this cluster at redshift 0.51 (luminosity distance 2891 Mpc), the mean observed frequency of 345 GHz translates into a rest frequency of 521 GHz and a rest wavelength of 576 microns. The expected signal is 0.425 mJy for a galaxy with 5E9 Msun of gas. Galaxies with more gas will be detected with higher S/N.
The correlator configuration is for a standard continuum measurement in Band 7.

With an angular diameter distance of 1277 Mpc, the 1" ALMA beam corresponds to a diameter of 6.2 kpc. This resolution is well matched to observed diameter of the bright central regions in the most gas-rich Virgo Cluster galaxies, such as NGC 4254 or NGC 4321 (Wilson et al. 2012).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cluster EDiscs 1301 - 7 blue galaxies at z=0.48

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
See ScienceGoal "Cluster GEEC 138" for a description of the equation and input parameters
For this cluster at redshift 0.48 (luminosity distance 2689 Mpc), the mean observed frequency of 345 GHz translates into a rest frequency of 511 GHz and a rest wavelength of 588 microns. The expected signal is 0.46 mJy for a galaxy with 5E9 Msun of gas. Galaxies with more gas will be detected with higher S/N.
The correlator configuration is for a standard continuum measurement in Band 7.

With an angular diameter distance of 1235 Mpc, the 1" ALMA beam corresponds to a diameter of 6.0 kpc. This resolution is well matched to observed diameter of the bright central regions in the most gas-rich Virgo Cluster galaxies, such as NGC 4254 or NGC 4321 (Wilson et al. 2012).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cluster EDiscs 1138 - 7 blue galaxies at z=0.48

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
See ScienceGoal "Cluster GEEC 138" for a description of the equation and input parameters.
For this cluster at redshift 0.48 (luminosity distance 2689 Mpc), the mean observed frequency of 345 GHz translates into a rest frequency of 511 GHz and a rest wavelength of 588 microns. The expected signal is 0.46 mJy for a galaxy with 5E9 Msun of gas. Galaxies with more gas will be detected with higher S/N.
The correlator configuration is for a standard continuum measurement in Band 7.

With an angular diameter distance of 1235 Mpc, the 1" ALMA beam corresponds to a diameter of 6.0 kpc. This resolution is well matched to observed diameter of the bright central regions in the most gas-rich Virgo Cluster galaxies, such as NGC 4254 or NGC 4321 (Wilson et al. 2012).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Galaxy clusters in the local universe are dominated by quiescent red galaxies, while blue star-forming galaxies are abundant in the field. An important unsolved problem in galaxy evolution is what are the mechanisms that preferentially quench star formation and alter galactic morphology in the cluster environment. Recent observations of the gas content of spiral galaxies in the Virgo Cluster and the field have shown that galaxies in the Virgo Cluster have lower specific star formation rates and star formation efficiencies, despite having similar total gas mass fractions. This suggests that gas removal may not play a strong role in quenching. Distinguishing between different proposed explanations, including gas stripping or biased galaxy formation, is possible with comparable observations of Virgo Cluster progenitors. We propose to measure the gas content in 35 blue star-forming galaxies in four such clusters at redshifts 0.44-0.51. We will use Band 7 continuum observations of dust, combined with an assumed gas-to-dust mass ratio and calibrated dust temperature, to detect galaxies with total gas masses > 5E9 Msun. Note: this project is a filler program in Cycle 2 (PI: Wilson).
